title-group.article-title: An Exploratory Evaluation Framework for e-Clinical Data Management Performance

article-meta.aff: 1The Catholic University of Korea, Seoul, South Korea

author-notes.corresp: HyunJu Lee, 222 Banpo-daero, Seocho-gu, Seoul 137-701, Korea Email: jan@catholic.ac.kr

abstract.p: Electronic data management is becoming important to reduce the overall cost and run-time of clinical trials with enhanced data quality. It is also imperative to meet regulated guidelines for the overall quality and safety of electronic clinical trials. The purpose of this paper is to develop an exploratory performance evaluation framework for e-clinical data management. This study performs a Delphi survey for 3 iterative rounds to develop an exploratory framework based on key informants’ knowledge. Four key metrics in the areas of infrastructure, intellectual preparation, study implementation, and study completion covering major aspects of clinical trial processes are proposed. Performance measures evaluate the extent of regulation compliance, data quality, cost, and efficiency of the electronic data management process. They also provide measurement indicators for each evaluation item. Based on the key metrics, the performance evaluation framework is developed in three major areas involved in clinical data management—clinical site, monitoring, and data coordinating center. From this initial attempt to evaluate the extent of electronic data management in clinical trials by a Delphi survey, further empirical studies are planned and recommended.

sec.title: 1. Background and Purpose
sec.p: In the past decade, the clinical trials market has grown in practice of evidence-based medicine. Along with this, there is a trend toward increasing investment in clinical research and reinforcement of system development. As the scope of clinical trials extends to a global setting and more safety issues are required, more cost-effective approaches are necessary. The utilization of electronic data management systems is the reason for this. Research 1 shows that electronically integrated data management can lead to high performance in the clinical trials industry along with its evolvement over time. Electronic data management systems play a particularly important role in their support by highly efficient and cost-effective data management with enhanced data quality. 2 –4

In reality, the Korean clinical trial market does not deeply recognize the important role of electronic data management. This is supported by the fact that there have been few academic studies related to electronic data management among studies on clinical trials while relatively low attention has been paid to data management in practical fields. Although the quality of clinical trials is considered to be critical to the successful achievement of trials, there has been little consideration of the influence of data management on the quality of clinical trials. Electronic data management is still considered as a mere tool to meet the target timeline of trials.

E-clinical data management refers to the management of clinical data led by computerized systems in clinical trials, which are represented by electronic data capture (EDC) systems. 2 Clinical sites are able to key in data while both data error checks and corrections can be simultaneously performed by data managers or monitors before completion of all data entry. This process nourishes and strengthens clinical trial processes and supports high performance in clinical data management. Electronic data management is becoming increasingly important to reduce the overall cost and run-time of clinical trials as well as to enhance data quality. 3,4 It is also necessary to meet regulated guidelines for the overall quality and safety of electronic clinical trials. 5 However, there are few rigorous standards that cover the “overall” clinical data management with EDC system utilization, although there are practical assessment tools in each pharmaceutical company basis or in the specific areas of evaluation concerns. 5
–10 Therefore, it is necessary to examine the intrinsic role of electronic data management by developing a performance evaluation framework.

This study provides implications for an initial attempt to evaluate the extent of electronic data management in clinical trials. The purpose of this paper, therefore, is to develop a performance evaluation framework in electronic clinical trial data management based on a literature and expert review in the industry. As part of the framework, this study proposes a set of key metrics that cover the major aspects of electronic data management in clinical trial processes. The declaration of each measure with the evaluation framework reveals important values to pursue in clinical trials—efficiency, data quality, cost, and regulatory compliance. In this study, a comprehensive framework is suggested to evaluate major aspects of e-clinical data management performance with a holistic perspective. Performance measures as well as detailed measurement indicators of a performance evaluation framework for e-clinical data management are proposed.

sec.title: 2.1 Literature and Expert Review for Initial Key Metrics
sec.p:
Previous studies and government guidelines have been reviewed to identify key features of e-clinical data management. Many studies utilizing EDC systems are case-based, dealing with specific diseases. Several publications describe advantages as well as challenges of managing data in clinical trials with EDC systems. 1
–4 Some of them try to quantify the effects of EDC systems, aimed at specific managerial concerns. Several studies 5
–8 focused on data quality by suggesting conceptual guidelines or assessing quality types. Lee and Choi 9 and Palvovic et al 10 show the measurement points of EDC systems’ efficiency. Pavlovic et al 10 conducted a cost simulation study for the electronic data collection process. Ene-Idordache et al 11 proposed electronic case report form (e-CRF) development to maintain compliance with regulations such as audit trails and authorization. In addition to academic studies, practical manuals, conference proceedings on clinical data management, 12,13 government guidelines and documents on policy related to Good Clinical Practice (GCP) 14 –16 are referred to for the analysis in this study. A set of performance measures has been drafted from this literature review, which includes major components of data management being applied to the clinical trial process.

By in-depth interviews, extracted performance measures were reviewed and revised for the initial key metrics with two data management (DM) experts in two particular clinical research organizations in August 2011. Those experts have 7 and 8 years of specialized experience in directing both domestic and global clinical data management with EDC systems, serving as professional DM trainers to foster human resources in a government-run organization, KONECT (Korea National Enterprise for Clinical Trials).

sec.title: 2.2 Key Informants’ Selection and Delphi Survey
sec.p: With the initial key metrics, an iterative survey process has been performed to reach a consensus among DM experts by the Delphi survey, a structured tool for expert problem solving in information systems research. 15 The Delphi survey is useful in exploratory areas where little research has been directed. 17,18

The experts’ eligibility as key informants for the Delphi survey is very critical as long as the method provides data objectively on the basis of expertise intuition. 15 Based on snowball sampling, 6 key informants were selected through a process of reference from one person to the next. The selection criteria are their experience and knowledge in the clinical data management field of clinical research organization (CRO). Experts’ information about affiliation, title, and work experience is shown in Table 1. In the table, participants' names and affiliations are listed by initials to preserve anonymity. The average work experience is 7 years, with a minimum of 4 maximum of 14 years in clinical trial fields beyond the general data management career. The system environment they have used is typically web based, mostly for phase III and postmarketing surveillance (PMS), and some of them for phases I and II. The number of clinical studies using EDC systems they have handled ranges from 10 to 22 out of 27 to 100 clinical trials in 2010. The number of clinical trials carried out in Korea, as a reference, was 475 in 2010.

fn.p: Participants’ names and affiliations are listed by initials to preserve anonymity.

sec.p: Three rounds of iterative surveys with 6 key informants were performed in August and September 2011; from August 25 through September 5; September 14 through 23; and September 26 through 30. Each question about performance categories, measures, and measurement indicators requires the levels of importance and current status score in a 5-point Likert scale. Open questions were asked for additional expert opinions. In completing each round, a content analysis was conducted through the rating scale method to apply to the next survey, integrating similar items and eliminating redundant content. Mean and standard deviation were calculated per each item in scoring the levels of importance and current status by an interval scale.

sec.title: 3.1 Key Metrics
sec.p: Four key metrics are categorized according to the e-clinical data management process: infrastructure, intellectual preparation, study implementation, and study completion. A brief description of the e-clinical data management process is as follows. For a study start-up, the project team must ensure that planning, communication, and skills are in place and validation systems are suitable to the study purpose and scope. This leads to protocol development and e-CRF generation based on study protocols. Clinical research coordinators (CRCs) begin to enter data from the time that the first subject is enrolled in a clinical site. While CRCs continue entering data, queries are created by data managers or in relation to clinical research associates (CRAs) so that data modification is handled and resolved in real time. The database is locked with the data managers’ approval in order to ensure no manipulation of study data during the final analysis once all data management activities are completed. To build up the key metrics, measurable and quantifiable performance measures are developed. Measurement indicators are suggested for each measure for evaluation purposes, and in total consist of 4 metrics, 19 performance measures, and 45 measurement indicators. Key metrics developed in this study focus on the “data management” area in clinical trials. The basic format of this study’s metrics for the electronic clinical trial “data management” is based on that of Stanley et al, 19 which describes the metrics for a clinical trial “study” itself.

The infrastructure metric refers to the measurement for the groundwork in the e-clinical data management process to provide hardware, software, and human resources. Technology researchers point to both organizational and technological features that thwart adoption of innovations. 20 The infrastructure metric is measured by a site’s ability in terms of DM skills given their phase, size, resources, and subject population. The infrastructure metrics are listed in Table 2 with Delphi results of each of three rounds. Every indicator shows a higher score than 3 as a mean, indicating “important” or “extremely important.” This is interpreted as a meaningful value according to the method of Marray et al 21 with a 75% positive response rate. The scores of the current status in the Korean industry are lower than those of the importance levels, however.

fn.p: A, all; C, current status; DM, data management; Imp, importance; M, monitoring; MI, measurement indicator; S, site.

sec.p: The intellectual preparation metric implies the measurement for the preparation of intellectual applications such as clinical study concepts, protocols, e-CRF, and data cleaning ideas. Beyond the level of designing, it checks whether to meet the advanced level by simplifying and standardizing the intellectual preparation process. The issue of simplification and standardardization requires high-level criteria to measure the extent of data management and aims for a strategic viewpoint. As intellectual applications are arranged in a more simplified and standardized manner, an accordingly more efficient and error-free data environment can be achieved. Table 3 shows Delphi results of importance with a satisfactory correlation to the data, with lower scores of the current status compared to the levels of importance.

fn.p: A, all; C, current status; DM, data management; Imp, importance; M, monitoring; MI, measurement indicator; S, site.

sec.p: The study implementation metric refers to the measurement for performance evaluation during clinical study implementation, starting from subject enrollment, data entry in each clinical site, and query management up to database lock. This metric particularly addresses the efficiency and data quality issue in implementing electronic data management. The extent of efficiency is measured in the overall implementation process by rapid enrollment, timeliness of data entry, response to query request, and database lock, due to the utilization of EDC systems. It also measures the level of data quality with the question of data discrepancy management between source data and CRF as well as protocol compliance between protocol and CRF. In this metric, regulatory compliance should also be of interest such as an audit trail and embedment of attributability controls and others. In Table 4, the value of “rapid enrollment” shows the largest gap between the levels of importance and the current status scores.

fn.p: A, all; C, current status; DM, data management; Imp, importance; M, monitoring; MI, measurement indicator; S, site.

sec.p: The study completion metric shows the measurement for data management activities associated with the completion of the study. The checkpoint to examine the performance of the overall clinical study involves not only the completeness of a study itself but also the timely and costless completion of the study enabled by the EDC systems. Table 5 shows lower scores of the current status than the levels of importance, which reflects low awareness of data management.

fn.p: A, all; C, current status; DM, data management; Imp, importance; M, monitoring; MI, measurement indicator; S, site.

sec.title: 3.2 Validity of Key Metrics
sec.p: As indicated previously, the basic structure of metrics in this research is taken from the study of Stanley et al, 19 which describes a network report card in an academic multicenter pediatric research network to discuss the effects of the performance measure tool. Based on the validation of the predetermined measurement tool since the implementation of PECARN (The Pediatric Emergency Care Applied Research Network) report card in 2005, this study checks the validity of the newly developed framework with Marray et al’s 21 method of a 75% positive response rate. Through an iterative process to distill the judgments of experts, this study presents an indicator validation with mean scores above 3.2 points in the rating scale method.

sec.title: 4. Development of Performance Evaluation Framework
sec.p: Key metrics become the basis of the performance evaluation framework and are rearranged by major data management areas in charge. Data management in the overall clinical trial process is generally performed in three areas: clinical research sites, data coordinating centers, and monitoring. Performance measures developed in key metrics are also newly set up for each DM area, making it possible to focus more on a specific data management area’s accountability.

sec.title: 4.1 Managerial Concerns
sec.p: The fundamental goals or managerial concerns that clinical data management tries to meet are data quality (D), efficient management (E), cost effectiveness (C), and regulatory compliance (R), popularly represented by GCP compliance. 2,10 This study builds performance measures to fit 4 of these managerial concerns. Each performance measure is placed in one or more categories of managerial concerns where it can enhance performance for the relevant goal out of the 4 (see Tables 6-8).

tr.th: Site PE Corresponding to Key Metrics

tr.td: Investigator understanding and commitment for use of EDC systems
EDC experience of investigator and CRC (work years)
Training depth and length for CRC (contents and hours per year)
Possibility of the linkage between EDC system and EMR
Promptness of target enrollment due to the auto-checking enabled by EMR linkage (enrollment days per subject)
Timeliness of data entry after the completion of informed consent form
Timeliness of response to manual query request from data center (run-time)
Timeliness of database lock after the last visit of last subject
Data completion check: number of manual queries per CRF for missing data
Real-world data check: number of manual queries per CRF for out of range
Data consistency check: number of manual queries per CRF for logical consistency
Rate of “dropout” of total subjects (according to AE, withdrawn consent, death, study medication withdrawn, visit violation, or others)
Rate of false “dropout” of total dropouts (accuracy of dropouts)
Rate of late detection of “dropout” (promptness of dropouts)
after the point of protocol amendment

fn.p: AE, adverse event; CRA, clinical research associate; CRC, clinical research coordinator; D, data quality; E, efficiency; EDC, electronic data capture; EMR, electronic medical records; MC, managerial concern; O, organizational effectiveness; PE, performance evaluation; R, regulatory compliance.

sec.title: 4.2.1 Infrastructure Metric
sec.p: Performance measures in the area of the clinical site examine how well a specific clinical site performs regarding e-clinical data management (see Table 6). The readiness of DM human resources should generally be checked at the time of groundwork in a clinical site.

As for the human resources support in a clinical site, it is important to measure the extent of team participation, such as investigator understanding of the use of EDC systems and EDC experience of the investigator and CRC as well as the communication frequency among CRC, CRA, and DM. Furthermore, the level of training and education for CRC such as training depth and length influences the effects of e-clinical data management. 2,13,20

sec.title: 4.2.2 Study Implementation Metric
sec.p: Two major managerial concerns during study implementation in a clinical site are efficiency and data quality. The goal toward efficiency can be measured and achieved through rapid enrollment, timely data entry, and timely manual query management. Timely data entry, timely manual query management, and timely database lock measure the extent of reduced time due to EDC systems. 9,10,13

This metric also measures the level of data quality during study implementation in terms of data discrepancy management and protocol compliance. Data discrepancy management measures the extent of discrepancy between source data and CRF. 5,6,13 Specifically, data discrepancy is checked in terms of missing data, out of range, and logical consistency, which are known to be the most frequent data error problems. Protocol compliance measures the discrepancy between the protocol and CRF. 7,8,13 Indicators for protocol compliance are proposed to measure how accurately and promptly the study protocol is followed. These indicators are the rate of dropouts of total subjects, rate of false dropouts of total dropouts, and rate of late detection of dropouts. 11,13

sec.title: 4.2.3 Study Completion Metric
sec.p: Overall, clinical sites are assessed according to the extent of enrollment success for a performance evaluation. 13,19 In order to account for site differences in volume and size, enrollment success is quantified as a percentage value based on the percentage of eligible subjects enrolled at each site per individual study.

In addition, the time factor of weeks after go-live can be measured for the study completion performance. Since the run-time for protocol development and e-CRF generation are already checked in the implementation metric, the time of go-live after the protocol amendment is placed down to the study completion phase. 10,12

sec.title: 4.3 Monitoring Performance Evaluation
sec.p: Performance measures in the area of monitoring examine how well monitoring performs for the e-clinical data management. The responsibility of monitoring is to monitor the conduct of a research trial, overseeing initiation, progress, and conduct to ensure the scientific integrity of collected data and the protection of rights and safety. Most performance measures in this framework share those of the clinical site performance evaluation framework, since monitoring activity is performed to watch every activity in clinical sites. Only the differences are declared in this section (see Table 7).

tr.th: Monitoring PE Corresponding to Key Metrics

tr.td: System integrity controls embedment in EDC
System change—easy traceability and reconciliation for prior e-records
System backup—regular backup and preservation of log records
Level of system security providing physical and logical device
Training depth and length for CRA (contents and hours/years)
Simplicity of verification between source data and e-CRF
System-restricted user permission secured to each access, modification, and management of e-CRF
Accountability for electronic records by electronic signature
Possibility of the linkage between EDC system and EMR
Promptness of target enrollment due to the auto-checking enabled by EMR linkage (enrollment days per subject)
Timeliness of response to manual query request from data center (run-time)
Timeliness of database lock after the last visit of last subject
Percentage of e-CRF review required (% of manual queries per total e-CRF data)
Number of manual queries per CRF
Data completion check: number of manual queries per CRF for missing data
Real-world data check: number of manual queries per CRF for out of range
Data consistency check: number of manual queries per CRF for logical consistency
Rate of “dropout” of total subjects (according to AE, withdrawn consent, death, study medication withdrawn, visit violation, or others)
Rate of false “dropout” of total dropouts (accuracy of dropouts)
Rate of late detection of “dropout” (promptness of dropouts)
Auto audit-trail completeness with system-generated dates and user name
System-led traceability of records by each subject
after the point of protocol amendment

fn.p: AE, adverse event; CRA, clinical research associate; CRC, clinical research coordinator; D, data quality; E, efficiency; EDC, electronic data capture; EMR, electronic medical records; GCP, Good Clinical Practice; MC, managerial concern; O, organizational effectiveness; PE, performance evaluation; R, regulatory compliance.

caption.p: Data coordinating center performance evaluation framework.

tr.th: DCC PE Corresponding to Key Metrics

tr.td: System integrity controls embedment in EDC
System change—easy traceability and reconciliation for prior e-records
System backup—regular backup and preservation of log records

Number of standardized data dictionaries (eg, sex, race, YN∼)
Reusability rate of standardized e-CRF forms
Number of days for e-CRF generation
Application of CDISC into the format of e-CRF (Y/N)

Number of days for system edit-checks generation (missing data, out of range, logical inconsistency)
System-restricted user permission secured to each access, modification, and management of e-CRFs
Accountability for electronic records by electronic signature
Possibility of the linkage between EDC system and EMR

Timeliness of response to manual query request from data center (run-time)
Timeliness of database lock after the last visit of last subject
Percentage of e-CRF review required (% of manual queries per total e-CRF data)
Number of manual queries per CRF
Data completion check: number of manual queries per CRF for missing data
Real-world data check: number of manual queries per CRF for out-of-range
Data consistency check: number of manual queries per CRF for logical consistency
Number of data management operators in charge of query management
Auto audit-trail completeness with system generated dates and user name
System-led traceability of records by each subject

fn.p: AE, adverse event; CDISC, Clinical Data Interchange Standards Consortium; CRA, clinical research associate; CRC, clinical research coordinator; D, data quality; DCC, data coordinating center E, efficiency; EDC, electronic data capture; EMR, electronic medical records; GCP, Good Clinical Practice; MC, managerial concern; MH, medical history; O, organizational effectiveness; PE, performance evaluation; R, regulatory compliance; SV, subject visit; YN, yes/no.

sec.p: In the clinical site performance evaluation framework, the intellectual preparation metric is not of interest. The intellectual application establishing in the intellectual preparation metric is mostly related to monitoring required by the sponsor of the study and data coordinating center. In the measure of protocol development simplification, the degree of verification between source data and e-CRF should be examined. For addressing regulatory compliance in the intellectual preparation metric, authorization also should be controlled for monitoring purposes, thus allowing regulators or sponsors to verify proper user access. Indicators are the degree of system-restricted user permission secured to each access, modification, and management of e-CRF and the extent of authority of electronic signature for electronic records’ accountability.

The study implementation metric is related to data quality and the regulatory compliance issue in monitoring. While the study implementation metric of the clinical site examines the basic data flow, that of monitoring assesses the close investigation of the clinical site’s DM performance based on regulations. The level of data quality from monitoring activity is measured by data discrepancy management and protocol compliance. Regulation compliance such as audit trail and attributability is another important concern in monitoring.

sec.title: 4.4 Data Coordinating Center Performance Evaluation
sec.p: The most extensive part of data management in the clinical trial process falls under the responsibility of the data coordinating center. Performance measures in the area of the data coordinating center interrogate how well the center performs for e-clinical data management (see Table 8).

sec.title: 4.4.1 Infrastructure Metric
sec.p: System integrity controls embedment in EDC systems is a measure to investigate the extent of regulation-compliant data management in the system infrastructure. System integrity needs to be analyzed with the following questions: whether system change is managed well in terms of traceability and reconciliation for prior electronic records, whether system backup is regularly and continuously performed, and whether the system is secured in both the physical and logical environments. 13 –15
In addition, team participation and training are considered to be determinants for successful data management performance in the data coordinating center. 13,20

sec.title: 4.4.2 Intellectual Preparation Metric
sec.p: Most parts of the intellectual preparation metric are under the supervision of the data coordinating center. The data coordinating center is responsible for e-CRF generation or creation of a data cleaning function such as system edit-checks in the study design stage. The intellectual preparation metric in this framework assesses not only the extent of generating functions, but also managerial capacity for more advanced functionality. That is, protocol development simplification examines how much to distinctively utilize reusable as well as unique portions in the format of protocol development. 12,13 This measure is not a basic requirement to prepare for the initial intellectual setup but an advanced element that affects the overall clinical trial process. The degree of simplicity of verification between source data and e-CRF falls under the responsibility of the data coordinating center as well. 12,13

The measure of e-CRF generation standardization checks the number of standardized forms of e-CRF and data dictionaries as well as the reusability rate of e-CRF forms. 7,12,13 It is necessary to analyze how long it takes to generate those forms, since this affects the overall timeline of study implementation. The indicator of Clinical Data Interchange Standards Consortium (CDISC) standards application into an e-CRF format is critical when global clinical trials are involved. 12,13 CDISC standards application is a performance measure to establish a standardized data collection and submission baseline and is rapidly becoming the industry standard.

Data cleaning standardization underlines system edit-checks generation. Indicators are the number of systems edit-checks, their reusability rate, and the number of days for the generation. 4,5,12 The higher the degree of standardization is in complicated e-CRF forms as well as in system edit-checks, the lower the rate of data error and the less time for data management they receive.

Authorization control embedment in EDC systems is a measure to inspect the secured user accessibility to satisfy regulatory compliance management and is applied to all multiple sites and centers. 13 –15 This measure examines whether systems allow restricted user access depending on their authority. Another vital checkpoint involves electronic signature to present accountability for relevant electronic records. 13,16

sec.title: 4.4.3 Study Implementation Metric
sec.p: The study implementation metric in the data coordinating center is related to efficiency, data quality, and regulatory compliance issues. Rapid enrollment measures the availability of the linkage between EDC and electronic medical records (EMR) and, if applicable, how much the enrollment time is reduced due to auto-checking enabled by EMR. 12 In the question of rapid enrollment, the interlock between the EDC system and EMR is a critically emerging issue in terms of integration and interoperability. The extent of efficiency is measured by timely manual query management and timely database lock. 9

As for data quality, the level of data discrepancy management should be checked. Data discrepancy management checks the percentage of e-CRF reviews required and the number of manual queries per CRF, which shows the ultimate data quality level enabled by the electronic systems. 19 It specifically counts the number of manual queries per CRF for missing data for a data completion check, out of range for real-world data check, and logical consistency for a data consistency check. 5,6,13
Audit-trail and attributability controls including other GCP compliance measures that are embedded in EDC systems are checkpoints to be measured for regulatory compliance. 13 –15

sec.title: 4.4.4 Study Completion Metric
sec.p: Cost reduction of data management is one of the most decisive measures to evaluate the level of the data coordinating center’s performance. 10,13 The metric analyzes study duration, total number of CRF forms, number of sites, number of patients per site, and data management staff prices for calculating data management cost. The extent of reduced cost can be checked by comparing these items in similar trials.

sec.title: 5. Discussion and Conclusion
sec.p: The aim of this study is to provide a framework for effective data handling from initial setup to database lock in the clinical data management process to facilitate quality improvement efforts. While there is reasonable understanding of the distinct characteristics of each clinical trial based on its study phase, size, and phase, this study tries to propose a comprehensive framework for general use.

Some academic and practical considerations regarding the evaluation framework are as follows. First, this study is one of the first attempts to establish a comprehensive performance evaluation framework covering all the major areas of managerial concerns that clinical data management is aimed at. This framework emphasizes specific managerial concerns such as efficiency, data quality, cost, and regulatory compliance to be improved through the overall data management process. For example, if the managerial concern regarding data quality needs to be improved, the e-CRF review in data discrepancy management needs to be concentrated on for improvement. By separately extracting each of 4 managerial concerns, more effective e-clinical data management is possible.

Second, there are large differences in terms of delivering skills as well as the role and quality of clinical data managers. Therefore, the framework developed in this study can be used as a self-assessment tool for the general requirement skills for e-clinical data management.

Third, this framework presents the accountability of each DM subprocess from infrastructure building to the study completion stage. For example, the standardized e-CRF generation is of interest to the intellectual preparation stage, not the study implementation stage. Additionally, it identifies the accountability of the DM area in charge. With this framework, data management relevant parties such as clinical site, data coordinating center, and monitoring would be more responsive to study deadlines, regulations, and timely data entry. For example, protocol development simplification is a performance measure under the responsibility of monitoring and the data coordinating center and recommends collaborative work between both centers with relevant responsibility.

Fourth, we can derive some insights toward the strategic use of e-clinical data management in this framework. Other than a basic evaluation for the operational use of data management such as timely data entry, several performance measures provide strategic viewpoints for high performance. For example, audit-trail embedment in EDC or data discrepancy management addresses the operational level, while protocol development simplification or CDISC standards application in the intellectual preparation metric pertain to the strategic level of data management.

Fifth, this framework can be utilized for DM strategy. Practical data accumulated from multiple sites will enable comparison of time-serial performance in a single clinical site or comparison of the performance of multiple centers, and thus efficiency and enhanced operation of data management can be anticipated. The accumulated data based on the framework would help establish industry standards to improve performance. Data managers also can selectively customize components of EDC systems depending on their level of electronic data management compared to the industry average.

Lastly, the following are some recommendations for future studies. First, extension of the scope of data management is suggested. This study covers up to the stage of database lock, but further studies covering up to the stage of data transfer and reporting are necessary for the completion of data management. Second, this is an initial study based on an expert survey. It is recommended that the scope of the survey be broadened under a test of validation and reliability based on statistical verification with a larger population of data managers.

ack.title: Acknowledgments
ack.p: The authors would like to thank YoungChul Lee, DM, Director of LSK Global PS, for reviewing the manuscript.

This research was presented at the 15th Annual Workshop for Clinical Data Management, DIA Japan, on January 26, 2012.
